Astronomy.question: On my honor, I have not given, received, nor witnessed any unauthorized aid on this test.
Which of the following class of stars is best known for being variable in the radio?
Which of the Following is True?
options: Cepheids are about the same temperature as the Sun but less massive.
Cepheids are about the same temperature as the Sun but more massive.
Cepheids are mostly colder than the Sun but the same mass.
Cepheids are mostly hotter than the Sun but the same mass.

Astronomy.question: Which of the following is NOT a subclass of Type II Cepheids?
The following light curve most likely belongs to an RRab pulsator. (Assuming that you have access to the light curve image).
Which of the following magnetic field strengths most accurately reflects that of a typical pulsar, in Teslas?
The period of a pulsar decreases with time.
Millisecond pulsars generally have much stronger magnetic fields than typical pulsars.
What is the name for the objects located in the molecular cloud in image 20?

This region in image 20 is located in what star-formation cloud complex?
What type of event produced the object in image 4?
The striped areas in Image 4 are thought to be the first direct evidence of what type of phenomena?
What is the name of the protostar in image 15?
What is the specific classification for the type of object in image 15?

What unique information resulted from the Chandra observational data for the protostar in image 15?
What letter on the H-R diagram shows the location of the object involved in the event that produced image 4?

What is the name of the binary system located in image 9?
The emissions coming from the system are likely dominated by what type of radiation?
What behavior is the white dwarf in image 9 undergoing that had never been observed before?
What is the number of the graph that shows this behavior?
The V Sagittae system illustrated in image 6 is predicted to undergo an extremely bright nova in 2083. What is unusual about the masses in this system that will cause the nova?
What will happen to the mass of the companion star in image 6?
What is the final outcome for the system in image 6?
What is the name of the region designated by the letter A on the H-R diagram?
What evolutionary transitions are happening to the stars in this region A on the H-R diagram?
What class and type of variability are these stars experiencing during these transitions?
What is the number of the image that shows the behavior of these types of stars located at letter A on the H-R diagram?
What is the image number for the illustration of the prototype for the types of variable stars located at letter A on the H-R diagram?
What letter shows the location of the star referenced from the previous question (question 25) on the H-R diagram?
What is the image number and type of object that contains a large number of Population II stars?
What is the name and image number of the star that is the prototype for the variable stars that can be found in the object in the previous question?
What letter on the H-R diagram shows the location of these stars?
This letter is located in what region of the H-R diagram?
What is the number of the graph that shows the behavior of the type of object from the previous two questions?
What is important about the behavior of these objects?
These stars are in the same class of variable stars as Mira variables. Why can’t Mira variables be used for the same purpose?
What two types of stellar objects are illustrated in the binary system in image number 14?
What two letters on the H-R diagram show their locations? Write your letters in alphabetical order.
Why has it taken until fairly recently to detect this type of dead cataclysmic system?
What is the name and image number of a catastrophic event in the Large Magellanic Cloud?

What is the number of the graph that shows the behavior from this type of event?

What is the difference in longevity for the two different end products in these images from the question above?

Some close binary systems with a white dwarf and accretion disk increase in brightness due to
instabilities within the accretion disk. What is the number of the graph that shows the behavior of this
type of dwarf nova system?

What is the number of the graph that shows the behavior of a recurrent nova type of binary
system that results from thermonuclear events on the surface of the white dwarf?
What is the name of the binary system illustrated in image number 16?
What physical process is unique for the white dwarf in image 16?
What is unique about the emissions from the system shown in image 16?

If fusion is causing the emissions, the emissions should come from the entire surface of the
white dwarf; however, they are coming from a much smaller area. Where are the emissions thought to
originate?

What are the numbers of the two graphs that show the spectrum and behavior for this system
in image 16? Write your answers in numerical order.

Consider an open cluster of stars. To study the cluster in detail, astronomers would like to establish the distance of the cluster. If the cluster is within 1000 Pc, what would be the most accurate way to establish distance to the cluster?
Say the cluster is now believed to be over 10,000 Pc away. Assuming it is possible, what method would be best to use to determine the distance to the cluster?
At the distances in the above two questions, what are two methods of determining distance that are impractical / unreliable?
answers: Direct parallax and moving cluster method

Astronomy.question: What principle can explain why the core begins to collapse before a supernovae?

You’re studying a globular cluster of stars and observe one star whose luminosity is changing over time. This prompts you to study the star more closely, and you observe that its spectral class is A and it has a mass about half that of the sun. What type of object is this?

You identified the spectral class of the star by looking at the spectrum taken in a survey of
the cluster. What is the most prominent feature that would have allowed you to identify its spectrum as
class A?

Given the relation MJ = -0.141 - 1.773 log(P) + 0.190 log(Z), and assuming it applies accurately, you make further measurements about the object, and determine it has a period of .63 days, a mass of .45 solar masses, a metallicity of .002, and an apparent magnitude of 10 at the wavelengths your colleagues were studying. How far away is the object?
In the equation MJ = -0.141 - 1.773 log(P) + 0.190 log(Z) , what does the subscript J stand for?
answers: Absolute Magnitude in the J band

Astronomy.question:
A follow up study of the same area discovers that there is dust partially obscuring the object
you were observing, causing extinction (loss of light due to absorption or scattering by the dust) at
the wavelengths you took your measurements at. You to need to correct your calculations! This study
reports an extinction of 20%, or that 20% of the light of the object (at these wavelengths) was absorbed
or scattered. What is the true distance to this object?

By coincidence, in your observations you discover there is a foreground star that is also of
interest. This star exhibits an average parallax motion of .4 arcseconds between its extreme points of the
sky. How far away is this object (in parsecs)?

This foreground object also appears to wobble by a magnitude of 2.5 milli-arcseconds (accord-
ing to data from the Gaia spacecraft) in addition to it’s average parallax motion, over a consistent period.
What could explain this?

Investigating the wobble of this foreground object further, you determine that the main star
has 90% of the mass, and that the total mass of this object is 5 times that of the Sun. Any companions
however are too faint to be directly observed. Assuming there is only one significant companion, what
radius (from the barycenter) must it orbit at? For simplicity we assume a model of a circular orbit. Give
your answer in AUs.
What is the period of this objects wobble?
From our observations above, what is the most likely candidate for the companion object?

From everything we know about this object, what specific type of variable star will it likely
evolve into?

You’re observing an open cluster of stars and performing spectral classification of the brightest stars. You notice that every star in your survey happens to lie on the main sequence. Assuming we are only measuring stars in the cluster itself, what spectral class are we least likely to observe? Why are these the least likely for you to observe?
answers: O class, because they are short-lived

Astronomy.question:
We now adjust our survey to surveying the luminosities of each star in the cluster at several
filters to measure the color index of each object. At each filter B, V, R, and I, which spectral class will
have the smallest apparent magnitudes in the cluster? (Assume relative distances between each star are
negligible compared to the distance to the cluster from you)

We are interested in one star in particular, in our survey. Let’s name it for referring to it in
our survey. Star has apparent magnitudes as follows:
MB = 2.02, MV = 2.32, MR = 2.45, MI = 2.74. What is the spectral and luminosity class of star ?

Given our measurements so far, what would be a good approximation of its radius? Answer in
terms of solar radii

Using these measurements, what is the approximate temperature of star ? If needed, you can
use Ballesteros’ formula to answer this:
T = 4600K (1/(0.92 (B-V)) +1/(0.92 (B-V) + 0.62))
Using the temperature you found above, what is the peak wavelength of this star?
What is the total luminosity of this object? Answer in terms of solar luminosities.
What is the next phase of this star’s evolution?
What will be the last element this star’s core is able to burn?
In one word, name any stellar property that can distinguish Type I and Type II Cepheids (Other than period).
Another name for Type II Cepheids is...
Stars along the Instability Strip pulsate via which mechanism (Write out the full name)?

The Period-Luminosity Relation is used to estimate either the Absolute Mangitude or Period
of a Classical Cepheid. Supposing the Absolute Magnitude of Delta Cephei to be -3.47, use the following
equation to estimate its period, rounding to the nearest number of days.
Mv = - [2.76 (log10(P) - 1.0)] - 4.16

A star must have at least 0.08 solar masses in order to burn hydrogen at its core. Assuming the
relation L M3.5, and the absolute magnitude of the Sun to be +4.83, calculate the absolute magnitude
that the least massive star on the main sequence could have.

The efficiency of hydrogen burning is approximately 0.7%, with only 10% of a star’s hydrogen
being consumed in the core. Using the mass and luminosity of the Sun (M = 1.989e30 kg and L=
3.826e26 W), estimate the duration of the Sun on the main sequence in years. (Hint: The luminosity is
the rate of energy burned per second)

We had previously given the mass-luminosity relation for a star on the main sequence to be
LM3.5 , and hinted at the fact that the lifetime of a star is inversely proportional to its luminosity. Using
the lifetime of the Sun calculated in the last problem, derive a relation for estimating the lifetime of a
main sequence star based on its mass, and use this to calculate the lifetime of a 0.08 M star.

answers: Line 3: int is used like a function to cast 2.0 to an integer, which is invalid.  Change int(2.0) to (int) 2.0
Line 5: You cannot add an integer to an array. Change it to j[0] = i;
Line 2: static and void should be lowercase. Change Static to static and Void to void.
Line 6: array[i,j] is invalid syntax to access elements of a 2D array. Change array[i,j] to array[i][j].
Line 4: printf is not a valid java command, and needs to be System.out.printf(...); Additionally, the first parameter is misformatted. Replace '%%%s' with '%s'.

7 0 false
31 4 false
24 3 false
19 3 false
53 8 true
25 5 true
40 4 false
35 5 true
